senses.de: Related to words or spoken language
senses.ex: The child has excellent verbal skills for his age.

Tips.title: Spoken Context
Tips.description: Use 'verbal' when emphasizing spoken skills over writing or nonverbal communication.
Tips.example: Her verbal articulation during the presentation was impressive.

Tips.title: Language Fluency
Tips.description: Mention 'verbal' to stress the fluency or expressive nature of someone's language ability.
Tips.example: His verbal fluency in Spanish surpasses his written skills.

Tips.title: Non-textual communication
Tips.description: 'Verbal' suggests that communication is oral, in contrast with text-based or sign language.
Tips.example: She prefers verbal instructions over emails.

senses.ex: She made a verbal commitment, promising to help.

Tips.title: Not Binding
Tips.description: 'Verbal' agreements often imply they are less formal and not legally binding like written contracts.
Tips.example: We have a verbal understanding, but nothing's on paper yet.

Tips.title: Commitment Level
Tips.description: 'Verbal' can indicate a preliminary commitment, before any formal actions are taken.
Tips.example: He gave a verbal agreement to join the meeting.

senses.de: Used to describe a noun in grammar
senses.ex: In the sentence 'fishing is fun', 'fishing' is a verbal noun.

Tips.title: Behavior Description
Tips.description: Use 'verbal' to describe certain behaviors or actions when expressed through language.
Tips.example: Verbal bullying can be as harmful as physical intimidation.

Tips.title: Emotional Expression
Tips.description: 'Verbal' can highlight emotional expression particularly when conveyed through words.
Tips.example: He often struggles with verbal expression of his feelings.

Tips.title: Grammar Usage
Tips.description: 'Verbal' in grammar indicates a word formed from a verb that functions like a noun.
Tips.example: 'Running' in 'Running is healthy' is a verbal noun because it names an activity.

Articulate.wordDefinition:
Articulate means to be able to express oneself clearly and effectively, with good grammar and vocabulary. It refers to one's ability to speak or write well.

For example, someone who is articulate can explain complex ideas in a way that is easy to understand, while someone who is verbal simply uses words to convey their thoughts, even if they are not expressed clearly or effectively.

Articulate is often used to describe someone who is an excellent communicator, while verbal is used more generally to describe someone who uses words to express themselves.

Overall, while both words are related to communication and language, articulate emphasizes the quality and effectiveness of expression, while verbal refers to the act of using words to communicate.

Communicative.wordDefinition:
Communicative refers to the ability of a person to communicate effectively with others using different means such as body language, facial expressions, and gestures apart from just speaking.

Communicative is a broader term that signifies the ability to communicate using different means, while verbal specifically pertains to spoken or written language.

Linguistic.wordDefinition:
Linguistic refers to language as a system of communication, including things like grammar, syntax, and semantics.

For example, if a linguist is studying the grammar of a language, they would be focusing on the linguistic aspects of the language, whereas if someone is giving a speech or writing an essay, they would be using verbal language to express their ideas.

Linguistic refers to the technical aspects of language and how it works, while verbal refers to the actual use of language to communicate ideas.

Oral.wordDefinition:
Oral refers to spoken communication, while the word verbal includes both spoken and written communication. Oral communication is applicable in situations where people speak to each other face-to-face or over the phone, while verbal communication is applicable in any situation where words are used, whether spoken or written, such as emails and messages.

For example, a conversation with friends is an example of oral communication, while a text message or email is an example of verbal communication.

Phonic.wordDefinition:
Phonic relates to sounds and pronunciation of words, particularly in terms of how letters and letter combinations create certain sounds.

Phonic refers to the sounds of words, while verbal refers to the words themselves.

Speak.wordDefinition:
Speak is a verb used to describe the action of communicating using words or speech. It usually refers to the act of producing sounds that correspond to particular meanings.

For example, when someone talks to you, they are speaking.

Verbal refers to language that is spoken or composed of words that are spoken. It describes something that is communicated using words or speech.

For example, a verbal agreement is one that is made through spoken words rather than in writing.

In simpler terms, speak refers to the action of using words or speech to communicate, while verbal describes something that is spoken or communicated using words.

Vocal.wordDefinition:
Vocal refers to sound produced by the voice or relating to the human voice.

In simpler terms, verbal is about using words, while vocal is about making sounds with your voice. Verbal is usually used when talking about what someone said or wrote, while vocal is usually used when talking about singing or making noises with your voice, like in a choir or a bird chirping.

quotes.Text: For me, I think that there's a lot missing from the recovery or the post-diagnosis side of treating patients. Once the diagnosis is made, I feel that care drops off tremendously, even though it is precisely the time that a patient needs help the most, even if they are not verbalizing it.
quotes.Title: American Journalist
quotes.Name: Susannah Cahalan

quotes.Text: Harassment doesn't just happen to 'social observers' and 'comedians' - women who express themselves publicly are reliably verbally attacked online and in person, not for their substance but for their form.
quotes.Title: American Journalist
quotes.Name: Faith Salie

quotes.Text: And the purpose of small talk is not to be controversial, clever or even interesting. It's simply to fill the silent void with a small gesture of common humanity. It's a spoken smile, a verbal handshake.
quotes.Title: British Actor
quotes.Name: Gyles Brandreth

quotes.Text: I have come to believe over and over again that what is most important to me must be spoken, made verbal and shared, even at the risk of having it bruised or misunderstood.
quotes.Title: American Poet
quotes.Name: Audre Lorde

quotes.Text: Again, I find it difficult to be taken care of and rarely acknowledge it, and every act he does registers, but I also just need to verbally acknowledge him and hug him.
quotes.Title: American Actress
quotes.Name: Patricia Heaton

quotes.Text: I started out as an artist, and what I do is verbal paintings. I paint a picture. Hopefully, you'll see the characters and what they're doing and what they're saying.
quotes.Title: American Comedian
quotes.Name: Jonathan Winters

quotes.Text: I've been chased. I've been pushed. I've been screamed at. I've been verbally abused. I've been afraid for my safety. But I did it all in the name of entertainment.
quotes.Title: Comedian
quotes.Name: Howie Mandel

quotes.Text: I'm the first guy to jump on somebody and pick a fight with them, at least verbally, I try to do it with some class and respect.
quotes.Title: American Mixed Martial Artist
quotes.Name: Frank Shamrock

quotes.Text: It's a feeling without a lid, of what you would do, physically, verbally, to protect the one thing that is your greatest love.
quotes.Title: English Actress
quotes.Name: Lena Headey

quotes.Text: I don't go through life verbalizing what I feel.
quotes.Title: American Astronaut
quotes.Name: Buzz Aldrin
